<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenStrict {
```scss
/**
 * Strict implementation of StringTokenizer
 * 
 * @param str
 * @param delim
 *            true = include NULL Token
 * @return
 */
static StringTokenizer getStringTokenizerStrict(String str, String delim, boolean strict) {
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(str, delim, strict);
    StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();

    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String s = st.nextToken();
        if (s.equals(delim)) {
            sb.append(" ").append(delim);
        } else {
            sb.append(s).append(delim);
            if (st.hasMoreTokens())
                st.nextToken();
        }
    }
    return (new StringTokenizer(sb.toString(), delim));
}

static void altStringTokenizer(StringTokenizer st) {
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        String type = st.nextToken();
        String one = st.nextToken();
        String two = st.nextToken();
        String three = st.nextToken();
        String four = st.nextToken();
        String five = st.nextToken();

        System.out.println(
                "[" + type + "] [" + one + "] [" + two + "] [" + three + "] [" + four + "] [" + five + "]");
    }
}

public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "Record|One||Three||Five";
    altStringTokenizer(getStringTokenizerStrict(input, "|", true));
}
```
}

In the given code, the issue is that the `nextToken()` method of the `StringTokenizer` class is not designed to handle empty fields correctly. Instead, you can use the `StringTokenizer` class with a `StringBuffer` to store the tokens and then manually handle empty fields.

The `getStringTokenizerStrict` method creates a `StringTokenizer` object and appends the tokens to a `StringBuffer` object. It then returns a new `StringTokenizer` object that reads from the `StringBuffer` object. This way, you can handle empty fields by manually appending a space and a tab to the `StringBuffer` object.

In the `altStringTokenizer` method, you can then read the tokens from the `StringTokenizer` object and handle empty fields by checking if the current token is empty and appending a space and a tab to the `StringBuffer` object.

In the `main` method, you can call the `altStringTokenizer` method with the `getStringTokenizerStrict` method to handle empty fields correctly.
